elements.content: A family of thiophene-based metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), [Zn­(L)­(BBI)·(H2O)2] (1) (BBI = 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)­bis­(imidazole)) and [Cd­(L)­(TPOM)0.75]·xS (2) (TPOM = tetrakis­(4-pyridyloxy-methylene) methane, S represents noncoordinated solvent molecules) was constructed by employing a new linear thiophene-functionalized dicarboxylic acid (benzo-(1,2;4,5)-bis­(thiophene-2′-carboxylic acid, H2L) to assemble with d10 ions in the presence of a flexible ancillary ligand under solvothermal conditions, which exhibit diverse structures. Most strikingly, both compounds 1 and 2 could be efficient luminescent sensory materials that are highly selective and sensitive to environmental contaminants, especially for Hg­(II), Cu­(II), Cr­(VI), and salicylaldehyde, and yet remain unaffected by other molecules that may coexit. Furthermore, this is the first report on MOF-based sensors capable of recyclable detection of Hg­(II), Cr­(VI), and salicylaldehyde so far. The luminescent sensing mechanism was studied in detail as well. In addition, compound 2 is one of the rare examples of high-performance MOFs trapping 2,4-dichlorophenol from the wasted methanol solution.

elements.content: During the last few decades, the increased release of hazardous chemicals into the environment from industrial and other anthropogenic processes has brought about severe global environmental problems because of their toxicity and nondegradability, and consequently they pose a persistent threat to human health. Therefore, it is of great importance to monitor environmental pollutants such as toxic ions, small organic molecules, etc., to reduce the risks of contamination. Nevertheless, the facile, visual, and quantitative detection of trace pollutants still remains a huge challenge in the field of environmental protection to date. Among many ongoing analytical methods used for identifying the environmental pollutants, fluorescence-based detection has apparent advantages in virtue of high sensitivity, selectivity, and easy manipulation and visualization, endowing it as an ideal alternative for the detection of pollutants.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

During the last few decades, the increased release of hazardous chemicals into the environment from industrial and other anthropogenic processes has brought about severe global environmental problems because of their toxicity and nondegradability, and consequently they pose a persistent threat to human health. Therefore, it is of great importance to monitor environmental pollutants such as toxic ions, small organic molecules, etc., to reduce the risks of contamination. Nevertheless, the facile, visual, and quantitative detection of trace pollutants still remains a huge challenge in the field of environmental protection to date. Among many ongoing analytical methods used for identifying the environmental pollutants, fluorescence-based detection has apparent advantages in virtue of high sensitivity, selectivity, and easy manipulation and visualization, endowing it as an ideal alternative for the detection of pollutants.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), also called porous coordination polymers, as a new type of crystalline porous material are comprised of inorganic metal ions or clusters with appropriate ligands. The permanent porosities within MOFs can not only potentially preconcentrate the analytes to realize improved sensitivity but also offer an ideal environment to accommodate substrates and thus induce differential recognition via intermolecular interactions between the framework and the analytes, which certainly makes them very promising as chemical sensors. In this regard, prominent progress has been made in the application of luminescent MOFs for sensing guest species, thus developing MOFs as excellent sensory materials. However, only very limited luminescent MOF-based sensors are capable of quantitative detection. Moreover, the sensitivity, stability, and especially the recyclability of MOF-based sensors need to be enhanced.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), also called porous coordination polymers, as a new type of crystalline porous material are comprised of inorganic metal ions or clusters with appropriate ligands. In this regard, prominent progress has been made in the application of luminescent MOFs for sensing guest species, thus developing MOFs as excellent sensory materials. However, only very limited luminescent MOF-based sensors are capable of quantitative detection. Moreover, the sensitivity, stability, and especially the recyclability of MOF-based sensors need to be enhanced.

elements.content: In addition, owing to tunable pore sizes and versatile structures, MOFs have been utilized as a new class of solid adsorbents recently and were found to work effectively to remove hazardous materials such as organosulfur or organic nitrogen compounds as well as dyes. Nevertheless, little work has been reported on using MOFs in the adsorptive removal of pesticides until now.

elements.content: It is well-known that conjugated thiophene ligands are important organic moieties in the syntheses of a variety of optoelectronic materials owing to their nature of good electron-transfer ability and structural rigidity. So far, MOFs constructed from thiophene-based ligands are rather limited, and the overwhelming majority for the system was based on thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylic acid. Interestingly, Lan and Su recently successfully assembled 3,4-dimethylthieno­[2,3-b]­thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylic acid with Zn­(II) to form S-containing MOFs for selective separation of transition-metal ions. Wang and Su reported a series of Zn­(II) coordination polymers prepared from a thiophene-derivatized carboxylate dithieno­[3,2-b:2′,3′-e]­benzene-2,6-dicarboxylic acid as the major ligand with different N-donor ligands as ancillary colinkers, which demonstrate interesting photoluminescence. In particular, Zhou and our groups have made use of benzo-(1,2;3,4;5,6)-tris­(thiophene-2′-carboxylic acid) to connect Cd2+, Fe2+, or Cu2+, and highly porous MOFs with fascinating gas adsorption behavior have been implemented.
elements.clean_text: It is well-known that conjugated thiophene ligands are important organic moieties in the syntheses of a variety of optoelectronic materials owing to their nature of good electron-transfer ability and structural rigidity. So far, MOFs constructed from thiophene-based ligands are rather limited, and the overwhelming majority for the system was based on thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylic acid. Interestingly, Lan and Su recently successfully assembled 3,4-dimethylthieno[2,3-b]thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylic acid with Zn(II) to form S-containing MOFs for selective separation of transition-metal ions. Wang and Su reported a series of Zn(II) coordination polymers prepared from a thiophene-derivatized carboxylate dithieno[3,2-b:2',3'-e]benzene-2,6-dicarboxylic acid as the major ligand with different N-donor ligands as ancillary colinkers, which demonstrate interesting photoluminescence. In particular, Zhou and our groups have made use of benzo-(1,2;3,4;5,6)-tris(thiophene-2'-carboxylic acid) to connect Cd2+, Fe2+, or Cu2+, and highly porous MOFs with fascinating gas adsorption behavior have been implemented.

elements.content: In this work, we designed a new linear thiophene dicarboxylate organic linker, namely benzo-(1,2;4,5)-bis­(thiophene-2′-carboxylic acid) (H2L, ), in which lone pair electrons of the sulfur atom with a large radius can be easily delocalized within the heterocyclic ring and definitely facilitate charge transfer interactions in the resulting molecular packing, thereby making it favorable for the development of photoluminescent materials. Meanwhile, two carboxyl moieties are arranged in a linear direction feasible for establishing bridges through versatile coordination fashions and mostly related to porosity of the final architecture, which would be beneficial to luminescence sensing and removal of pollutants.

Meanwhile, two carboxyl moieties are arranged in a linear direction feasible for establishing bridges through versatile coordination fashions and mostly related to porosity of the final architecture, which would be beneficial to luminescence sensing and removal of pollutants.

elements.clean_text: 1  Structures of the Thiophene Dicarboxylate and Flexible Ancillary Ligands Used in This Work

elements.content: In this contribution, by employing the H2L ligand to assemble with d10 ions in the presence of the flexible ancillary ligand (), two three-dimensional (3D) microporous MOFs were successfully fabricated: [Zn­(L)­(BBI)·(H2O)2] (1) (BBI = 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)­bis­(imidazole)) and [Cd­(L)­(TPOM)0.75]·xS (2) (TPOM = tetrakis­(4-pyridyloxy-methylene) methane, S represents noncoordinated solvent molecules) under solvothermal conditions, which show structural diversity. Most strikingly, both compounds could be efficient luminescent sensory materials for highly selective and sensitive to environmental contaminants, especially for Hg­(II), Cu­(II), Cr­(VI), and salicylaldehyde, and yet remain unperturbed by the coexistence of other molecules. Furthermore, the sensors can be reused at least 4–5 times after simple regeneration. To date, this is the only example of MOF-based sensors which are capable of recyclable detection of Hg (II), Cr­(VI), and salicylaldehyde. In addition, the luminescent sensing mechanism was studied in detail. More interestingly, compound 2 represents one of the rare examples of high-performance MOFs that can trap toxic pesticides and is an effective sorbent toward 2,4-dichlorophenol from contaminated methanol solution.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used without further purification. Ligand TPOM was prepared by literature methods. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on Varian Mercury VX400 instrument at ambient temperature with TMS as the internal reference. Low-resolution mass spectra were run on a Thermo DSQII. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a PerkinElmer 240 analyzer. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were performed (4000–400 cm–1) on a Bruker TENSOR 27 as KBr pellets. Thermal gravimetric experiments were recorded on a 2960 SDT thermogravimetric analyzer under N2 atmosphere from room temperature to 700 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were taken by a Rigaku MiniFlex2 diffractometer with a Cu target tube over the 2θ range of 5–40°. Fluorescence spectra were acquired on a Varian Cary Eclipse Fluorescence spectrophotometer equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature. The UV–visible absorption spectra were obtained on a UV-2501 spectrophotometer in the range of 250–800 nm. Atomic absorption spectra (AAS) were determined on a GBC AVANTA M. A high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) separation experiment was performed on an Agilent 1100 System.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used without further purification. Ligand TPOM was prepared by literature methods. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on Varian Mercury VX400 instrument at ambient temperature with TMS as the internal reference. Low-resolution mass spectra were run on a Thermo DSQII. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a PerkinElmer 240 analyzer. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were performed (4000-400 cm-1) on a Bruker TENSOR 27 as KBr pellets. Thermal gravimetric experiments were recorded on a 2960 SDT thermogravimetric analyzer under N2 atmosphere from room temperature to 700 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were taken by a Rigaku MiniFlex2 diffractometer with a Cu target tube over the 2θ range of 5-40°. Fluorescence spectra were acquired on a Varian Cary Eclipse Fluorescence spectrophotometer equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature. The UV-visible absorption spectra were obtained on a UV-2501 spectrophotometer in the range of 250-800 nm. Atomic absorption spectra (AAS) were determined on a GBC AVANTA M. A high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) separation experiment was performed on an Agilent 1100 System.

elements.content: Into a flask flushed with argon, 2,5-dibromo-1,4-benzenedicarboxaldehyde (2 g, 6.85 mmol) and K2CO3 (3.8 g, 27.5 mmol) were added to 30 mL of DMF. After that, ethyl 2-mercaptoacetate (1.5 mL, 13.7 mmol) was added dropwise to the mixture, followed by refluxing for 20 h. The reaction mixture was then brought to room temperature and poured onto a water/ice mixture. The formed beige precipitate was filtered, washed with water, and dried under air. The crude product was purified by silica gel chromatography (CH2Cl2:petroleum ester, 2:1) to afford benzo-(1,2;4,5)-bis­(thiophene-2′-carboxylic acid ethyl ester) (0.98 g, 43%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6, δ ppm): 8.74 (s, 2H), 8.26 (s, 2H), 4.37–4.42 (m, 4H), 1.35 (t, 6H). EI MS m/z: 334 (100%). MP: > 300 °C.

elements.content: Ester (1 g, 3 mmol) and sodium hydroxide (7.88 g, 0.20 mol) were refluxed in ethanol/water mixture (200 mL) overnight. The resulting solution was acidified, and the formed precipitate was filtered off and washed with water, yielding pure acid benzo-(1,2;4,5)-bis­(thiophene-2′-carboxylic acid) (1.58 g, 95%) of sufficient purity. Anal. Calcd for C12H6O4S2: C, 51.79; H, 2.17%; found: C, 51.91; H, 2.21. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6, δ ppm): 8.74­(s, 2H) 8.21 (s, 2H). EI MS m/z: 278 (100%). MP: > 300 °C.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of both 1 and 2 were mounted onto thin glass fibers in air. The X-ray diffraction data of compounds 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex DUO CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 298 and 173 K, respectively. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using full-matrix least-squares procedures based upon F 2 values. For compound 2: the free solvent molecules were chemically featureless to refine using conventional discrete-atom models. Thus, the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was applied to calculate the diffraction contribution from guest molecules, thereby yielding a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities. The subsequent refinements were based on the new data generated. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for compounds 1 and 2 are summarized in . Select bond lengths and angles are provided in Table S1. CCDC numbers are 1498478 and 1498479 for 1 and 2, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Suitable single crystals of both 1 and 2 were mounted onto thin glass fibers in air. The X-ray diffraction data of compounds 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex DUO CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 298 and 173 K, respectively. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using full-matrix least-squares procedures based upon F 2 values. For compound 2: the free solvent molecules were chemically featureless to refine using conventional discrete-atom models. Thus, the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was applied to calculate the diffraction contribution from guest molecules, thereby yielding a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities. The subsequent refinements were based on the new data generated. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for compounds 1 and 2 are summarized in . Select bond lengths and angles are provided in Table S1. CCDC numbers are 1498478 and 1498479 for 1 and 2, respectively.

Compound 1 crystallizes as a monoclinic system with the centric C2/m space group. There are half of a Zn­(II) atom, half of an L2– anion, half of a BBI bridge, and one disordered free water molecule in the asymmetric unit of 1. As manifested in a, the Zn­(II) center site in a tetrahedral coordination geometry is defined by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two individual L2– moieties [d Zn–O ranging from 2.037(3) to 2.065(4) Å] and two nitrogen atoms from different BBI ligands [d Zn–N = 1.961(3) Å]. Each L2– anion is linked to two Zn­(II) centers by monodentate coordination fashions, and each flexible BBI is attached to two Zn­(II) ions with two terminal imidazole groups adopting trans-configuration, producing a 3D porous framework with dimensions of ca. 14.2 × 21.5 Å2, 22.4 × 18.7 Å2, and 12.1 × 15.2 Å2 (atom-to-atom distance) along a-, b- and c-directions. Such large cavities induce 4-fold interpenetration of the network, which still retains 36.6% (1161.2 out of the 3175 Å3 unit cell volume) solvent accessible void volume after interpenetration. Notably, microporous channels with areas of 7.9 × 5.7 Å2 along the c-axis in 1 are present considering van der Waals distances. Apparently, the free spaces in 1 are occupied by structural disordered free aqua molecules. Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [Zn(L)(BBI)⋅(H2O)2] (1)

Compound 1 crystallizes as a monoclinic system with the centric C2/m space group. There are half of a Zn(II) atom, half of an L2- anion, half of a BBI bridge, and one disordered free water molecule in the asymmetric unit of 1. As manifested in a, the Zn(II) center site in a tetrahedral coordination geometry is defined by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two individual L2- moieties [d Zn-O ranging from 2.037(3) to 2.065(4) Å] and two nitrogen atoms from different BBI ligands [d Zn-N = 1.961(3) Å]. Each L2- anion is linked to two Zn(II) centers by monodentate coordination fashions, and each flexible BBI is attached to two Zn(II) ions with two terminal imidazole groups adopting trans-configuration, producing a 3D porous framework with dimensions of ca. 14.2 × 21.5 Å2, 22.4 × 18.7 Å2, and 12.1 × 15.2 Å2 (atom-to-atom distance) along a-, b- and c-directions. Such large cavities induce 4-fold interpenetration of the network, which still retains 36.6% (1161.2 out of the 3175 Å3 unit cell volume) solvent accessible void volume after interpenetration. Notably, microporous channels with areas of 7.9 × 5.7 Å2 along the c-axis in 1 are present considering van der Waals distances. Apparently, the free spaces in 1 are occupied by structural disordered free aqua molecules. Further topological analysis reveals that 1 can be described as a 4-connected dia net with a topology symbol of 66 (d).

elements.content: Interestingly, compound 2 crystallizes in the chiral space group P42212 with a Flack parameter of 0.52(3), suggesting inversion twinning with a 0.48:0.52 domain ratio. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of one Cd­(II) atom, one L2– moiety, and one-half and one-quarter crystallographically distinct TPOM bridges. As demonstrated in a, the Cd­(II) centers adopt a distorted pentagonal bipyramid arrangement connected by four carboxylate oxygen donors from two independent L2– parts [d Cd–O varying from 2.295(13) to 2.620(9) Å] and three nitrogen atoms from separate TPOM bridges [d Cd–N ranging from 2.308(5) to 2.335(6) Å]. Obviously, each L2– moiety fixes to two Cd­(II) sites with both deprotonated COO groups assuming bidentate-chelating coordination mode, while each flexible TPOM is linked to four Cd­(II) atoms, resulting in a noninterwoven 3D framework. There exist three kinds of open channels with sizes of 6.8 × 6.8, 6.8 × 4.0, and 6.6 × 3.1 Å2 along the a-axis, considering van der Waals distances (b). The effective free volume of 2 is ∼76% of the crystal volume (14979 of the 19602 Å3 unit cell volumes) upon removal of the guest molecules. By simplification of Cd­(II) centers and TPOM moieties as 5- and 4-connected nodes, respectively, the entire framework of 2 can be topologically represented as a (5, 4, 4) trinodal net with point symbol of (4.55.62.7.8)4(54.62)­(42.54)2 (c).

elements.content: The solid-state photoluminescence (PL) emission spectra of the free ligand H2L and compounds 1 and 2 were investigated under ambient temperature. Both compounds exhibit strong peaks centered at 410 nm (λex = 310 nm for 1 and λex = 280 nm for 2, Figure S3) with an obvious red-shift in respect to H2L (λem = 370 nm, λex = 300 nm). Due to their d10 configuration, the fluorescent emissions are neither metal-to-ligand nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer because Zn2+ or Cd2+ ions do not easily oxidize or reduce, which might be ascribed to the ligand-centered emission in nature. Generally, the porosity of compounds 1 and 2 provide a suitable platform for further luminescence sensing of ions and small organic molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties

The solid-state photoluminescence (PL) emission spectra of the free ligand H2L and compounds 1 and 2 were investigated under ambient temperature. Both compounds exhibit strong peaks centered at 410 nm (λex = 310 nm for 1 and λex = 280 nm for 2, Figure S3) with an obvious red-shift in respect to H2L (λem = 370 nm, λex = 300 nm). Due to their d10 configuration, the fluorescent emissions are neither metal-to-ligand nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer because Zn2+ or Cd2+ ions do not easily oxidize or reduce, which might be ascribed to the ligand-centered emission in nature. Generally, the porosity of compounds 1 and 2 provide a suitable platform for further luminescence sensing of ions and small organic molecules.

Sensing of Ions

Mercuric ion (Hg2+), as one of the most toxic and nonbiodegradable heavy metal ions, definitely can cause adverse effects on human health, particularly in the central nervous system. It should be noted that exposure of Hg2+ even at low concentrations will lead to digestive, kidney, and neurological diseases.

elements.content: Copper (Cu2+) is one of most essential biological metal ions and plays vital roles for living organisms. It is very important to intake appropriate Cu2+ in the daily diet to preserve our health as a trace dietary mineral. The dysregulation in the cellular homeostasis of Cu2+ may lead to some neurodegenerative disorders related to Wilson’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease.

elements.content:
Thus, the development of methods for the sensitive analysis of these ions is very urgent, which is of great importance in the field of environmental protection and food safety.

To exploit the potential of 1 for detecting cations, the suspensions of 1/cation were prepared by the fine grinding of 1 (3 mg) dispersed in aqueous solutions (3 mL) individually containing 1.0 × 10–2 M of M­(NO3) x (M = NH4 +, Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Mn2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Ag+, Cd2+, and Hg2+) for sensing studies. As illustrated in a, the fluorescence responses of 1 strongly depend upon the cations, especially Hg2+ with the most significant quenching behavior. When 400 μM of Hg2+ solution was involved, nearly 80% of the initial PL intensity was quenched, implying that compound 1 can be considered as a promising sensor of Hg2+ through fluorescence quenching (turn off). Meanwhile, the changes of emissive responses with different concentrations of Hg2+ introduced into emulsions of 1 were measured. Obviously, the emission intensities decline gradually with the increased concentrations of Hg2+. Quantitatively, the quenching effect can be approximately illustrated by the Stern–Volmer Equation I 0/I = 1 + K SV[M], wherein the values I 0 and I are the PL intensities of the suspension of MOF in the absence and presence of analytes, respectively. [M] represents the molar concentration of analytes, and K SV is related to Stern–Volmer quenching constant. Figure S4 shows the Stern–Volmer quenching curve describing I 0/I as a function of Hg2+ concentration in the wide range of 0–600 μM with a linear fit coefficient of 0.9986 and a K sv value of 9390 M–1, which is superior to the value (4550 M–1) for amino-decorated MOF utilized for detection of Hg2+ in aqueous solution, demonstrating its obvious quenching effect on the PL intensity of 1. Particularly, the quenching can be visually observed under usual UV light, as exemplified in the inset of a. As far as we know, MOF materials as luminescent sensors for Hg2+ are very rare.

elements.content: In particular, it is found that the PL intensities of 1 in Hg2+-M mixed cations system (M = NH4 +, Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Mn2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Ag+, Cd2+) remain comparable to that of 1 in pure Hg2+ suspension. Clearly, the detection of Hg2+ for compound 1 in aqua suspension is free from the interference of other cations (a), further indicating that 1 exhibits good selectivity to the Hg2+ ion. Strikingly, the turning on the luminescence of compound 1 was achieved by centrifugation of the suspensions and simply washing them several times with distilled water after the sensing process. Indeed, the quenching and regeneration cycles can be repeated at least 5 times (b) without loss of its PL intensity and quenching efficiency (the quenching efficiency was estimated from the formula (I 0 – I)/I 0 × 100%), demonstrating the superior recyclability and stability of 1 for sensing applications.

elements.content: Clearly, the Cu2+-selective fluorescent chemosensor of compound 2 was also free from interference by other competing cations (Figure S6). The apparent selective and sensitive detection of Cu2+ in water encouraged us to further explore the sensing ability of compound 2 under a well-established physiological buffer solution to mimic the living cell environment (0.02 M HEPES aqueous solution, pH 7). Remarkably, the sensing function of compound 2 for Cu2+ ion under such a simulated physiological condition closely resembles that of compound 2 investigated in pure aqueous environment (), highlighting the potential of compound 2 as a luminescent sensor in a biological system.

elements.content: The mechanism of luminescent quenching of compounds 1 and 2 individually induced by Hg2+/Cu2+ can be proposed that guest metal ions may diffuse into the pore of compounds 1 and 2 and interact with their framework via weak interaction forces involving ion–dipole, dipole–dipole, dipole–induced dipole, thereby most likely decreasing the energy-transfer efficiency within H2L. Moreover, the d–d transition of Cu2+ also wasted the energy of the system. In order to clarify the origin of PL quenching for compounds 1 and 2 toward different metal ions, the concentrations of Hg2+ and Cu2+ in the filtrates respectively from mixtures of compound 1 (3 mg/3 mL) and Hg2+ (500 μM) or compound 2 (3 mg/3 mL) and Cu2+ (500 μM) in aqua were measured. Atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) measurements demonstrate that the concentrations of Hg2+ and Cu2+ in the filtrates decrease to 138 and 250 μM, respectively, accompanied by the increasing of Hg2+ (2.30%) and Cu2+ (1.85%) contents in metal ion-loaded samples of 1/Hg2+ and 2/Cu2+, which may indicate the possibility of guest metal ions diffusing into the pores of compounds 1 and 2. After sensing, the Hg2+ ions in the pores of compound 1 can be almost removed through washing (Table S2), thereby benefiting luminescence recovery. On the contrary, the PL intensity for compound 2 toward the Cu2+ ions could not regenerate under identical conditions. It should be noted here that the guest metal ion Hg2+ is a soft acid, which has a weaker affinity to O donors in the framework of 1, endowing relatively easy removal of Hg2+ after washing; therefore luminescence intensity of 1 is recyclable, as demonstrated above. Unlike Hg2+, Cu2+ is a borderline metal center which allows for preferential interactions with O donors in the framework of 2, leading to relatively difficult leakage of Cu2+ from 2 after washing (Table S2); thus, luminescence intensity of compound 2 cannot recover.

elements.content: Simultaneously, aqueous solutions containing a variety of anions (F–, Cl–, Br–, I–, OAc–, SO4 2–, CO3 2–, HCO3 –, NO3 –, NO2 –, ClO4 –, PO4 3–, and Cr2O7 2–) at the same concentration (1.0 × 10–2 M) were prepared, and their effects on fluorescence intensity of 1 and 2 were conducted. The results show that PL intensities of the different suspensions are largely dependent on the various anions. The analytes, such as halide ions, OAc–, SO4 2–, HCO3 –, NO3 –, NO2 –, and ClO4 – did not cause any marked variance in the PL intensity, whereas other anions, in particular Cr2O7 2–, significantly depressed PL intensity (a and S8), indicating the feasibility of both 1 and 2 as a fluorescent probes toward Cr­(VI) in aqueous solution. To further assess the ability of 1 and 2 to sense trace amounts of Cr­(VI) in water, fluorescence quenching titrations were performed by introducing various concentrations of Cr2O7 2– into the resulting emulsions of 1 and 2. From b and S9, it can be seen that the PL intensities of 1 and 2 drop remarkably as the added Cr6+ concentration increased. Furthermore, plotting the I 0/I vs the Cr6+ concentration gives a straight line titration curve with a wide response range of 0–300 μM; the slope of K SV was deduced to be 11680 M–1 for 1 and 13450 M–1 for 2 (Figure S10), which is comparable to that reported for functional fluorescent aramids (11600 M–1) used for Cr­(VI) detecting in DMSO/water.

elements.content: The PL intensities of compounds 1 and 2 dispersed in H2O with addition of Cr2O7 2– (600 μM) were then subjected to other different anions (600 μM, anion = halides, OAc–, SO4 2–, CO3 2–, HCO3 –, NO3 –, NO2 –, PO4 3–, and ClO4 –), which have been tested for further investigation on the anti-interference ability of the sensors. Clearly, the fluorescence response of compounds 1 and 2 toward Cr­(VI) were nearly unaffected, indicating that both compounds are free from the interference of other anions and exhibit good selectivity to the Cr­(VI) ion (a and S12). Remarkably, the luminescence for both compounds 1 and 2 can be easily switched on through centrifugation of the dispersion and subsequent washing with distilled water after completing detection. The initial fluorescence intensity is essentially retained even after 5 cycles, and the quenching efficiency of every cycle is over 82%, indicating excellent recyclability (b and S13) and stability for probe applications.

elements.content: Salicylaldehyde (SA) is a spice and is also an important intermediate product used widely both in organic and drug synthesis. However, this colorless oily liquid has a bitter almond odor at higher concentrations, which has been proven to be irritating to the respiratory tract, eyes, and skin of humans and thereby induces cough or chest pain after inhalation. Additionally, salicylaldehyde is flammable and poisonous. As a result, the qualitative and quantitative chemical analyses of the salicylaldehyde should be performed accurately for these applications and potential hazards.
elements.clean_text:
Sensing of Small Organic Molecules

Salicylaldehyde (SA) is a spice and is also an important intermediate product used widely both in organic and drug synthesis. However, this colorless oily liquid has a bitter almond odor at higher concentrations, which has been proven to be irritating to the respiratory tract, eyes, and skin of humans and thereby induces cough or chest pain after inhalation. Additionally, salicylaldehyde is flammable and poisonous. As a result, the qualitative and quantitative chemical analyses of the salicylaldehyde should be performed accurately for these applications and potential hazards.

elements.content: Ethanol solutions containing various aldehydes, including formol, acetaldehyde, and salicylaldehyde were prepared, and their effects on PL intensity of compounds 1 and 2 were investigated for aldehyde sensing. It was found that the emissions of 1 and 2 can be readily quenched by salicylaldehyde, which almost disappeared at SA content of 0.0167 and 0.0133 vol % ( and S15), respectively, demonstrating that both compounds are highly sensitive to salicylaldehyde and thereby underlining the bright potential of compounds 1 and 2 for the detection of salicylaldehyde in EtOH.

elements.content: To evaluate the potential of 1 and 2 for the sensing of SA, their luminescent behaviors toward SA at different contents in ethanol emulsions were examined carefully. As depicted in , for compound 1, the reduction in luminescence intensity is proportional to the incremental addition of SA at concentrations from 0 to 450 μM, and the slope of K SV was calculated to be 4453 M–1 deduced from Stern–Volmer equation. For compound 2, the K SV value was 3477 M–1 for SA in the range of 0–900 μM from Stern–Volmer model (). The quenching effect is higher than the value of existing Tb-MOF fluorescent sensor comprising a triphenylamine moiety for SA, showing that small organic molecule SA apparently exerts quenching effects on the fluorescence of compounds 1 and 2.

elements.content: The competition experiment of SA with the coexistence of other aldehydes (formol and acetaldehyde) was also performed. It is very encouraging that the addition of other aldehydes has negligible effects on the sensing functions of 1 and 2 for SA ( and Figure S17). Both compounds 1 and 2 should not only display highly specific recognition of SA but also be highly stable and thus easily recycled for long-term usage. After being recovered using filtration and washing with ethanol, compounds 1 and 2 could be subsequently used in the successive runs. It was found that even after the fourth run, the regenerated counterparts still exhibit very high quenching efficiencies of 88 and 91% for 1 and 2, respectively, thus revealing that both compounds are indeed superior chemical sensors for SA.

elements.content: To our knowledge, MOF materials as luminescent sensors for aldehydes have been little-reported, although many types of MOFs as luminescent probes of cations, anions, and other organic small molecules are well-documented. In addition, the mechanism for the quenching effects of SA has been also investigated. The electron-withdrawing -HCO group definitely plays a vital role in luminescence quenching, and the fluorescence attenuation is presumably ascribed to a photoinduced electron-transfer (PET) mechanism from an excited state of MOF to the electron-deficient salicylaldehyde. To gain more insight into the sensing mechanism of compounds 1 and 2 toward SA, the HOMO and LUMO orbital energies of aldehyde analytes have been calculated by density functional theory at the B3LYP/6-31G* level (). Clearly, the LUMO energy level of salicylaldehyde is lower than those of other aldehydes analytes (formol and acetaldehyde), implying that the electron affinity of salicylaldehyde is relatively higher over other aldehydes, which facilitates the electrons to transfer from the HOMO of compounds 1 and 2 to the LUMO of the salicylaldehyde upon excitation, and hence, a more effective fluorescence quenching behavior is given.

elements.content: The wide use of organic pesticides in modern agriculture to enhance output has brought about intense public concern regarding the environment, healthiness, and food safety owing to their intrinsic high toxicity and nondegradability. Compared with many available methods such as distillation, membrane extraction, and electrolysis, removal of pesticides by adsorption technology has become one of the competitive techniques due to its high efficiency and simple operation. Therefore, developing new materials with high removal efficiency toward pesticides is of paramount importance for public security and health protection.
elements.clean_text:
Pesticide Removal

The wide use of organic pesticides in modern agriculture to enhance output has brought about intense public concern regarding the environment, healthiness, and food safety owing to their intrinsic high toxicity and nondegradability. Compared with many available methods such as distillation, membrane extraction, and electrolysis, removal of pesticides by adsorption technology has become one of the competitive techniques due to its high efficiency and simple operation. Therefore, developing new materials with high removal efficiency toward pesticides is of paramount importance for public security and health protection.

elements.content: Inspired by the larger porous structures of compound 2, herein, 10 mg of finely ground powder of compound 2 were soaked in 10 mL of methanol solution with bisphenol A (5 ppm), 2,4-dichlorophenol (5 ppm), and triclosan (5 ppm), which were mixed thoroughly with magnetic stirring and sonicated for 10 min. The mixture was kept for approximately 30 min at ambient temperature, and then the clear solution of the residual pesticides was separated after centrifugation. HPLC has been applied to check the removal efficiency of compound 2 toward pesticides (). The residual pesticides can be separated clearly by HPLC with retention times of 5.8, 10.2, and 13.3 min for bisphenol A, 2,4-dichlorophenol, and triclosan, respectively. The removal efficiencies of compound 2 are thus determined to be 41.5, 77.5, and 65.2% toward bisphenol A, 2,4-dichlorophenol, and triclosan ( and S18), respectively, based on the peak areas established by an external standard of the individual pesticides, as listed in . Further, three kinds of other pesticides were added into fresh methanol solution under otherwise the same conditions as those of the above adsorption experiments, and the removal efficiency is calculated to be 7.3% for carbofuran, 26.7% for carbaryl, and 11.7% for pirimicarb ( and S18), respectively. Evidently, compound 2 exhibits an excellent performance in adsorbing 2,4-dichlorophenol, and such selective removal of 2,4-dichlorophenol in methanol may be ascribed to the size-sieving effect, considering that toxic 2,4-dichlorophenol possesses a relatively smaller size, which may facilitate diffusion into the pores. To the best of our knowledge, MOFs with high-performance trapping of toxic pesticides are rarely reported, and compound 2 represents an excellent sorbent for the effective removal of 2,4-dichlorophenol from the wasted methanol solution.

Further, three kinds of other pesticides were added into fresh methanol solution under otherwise the same conditions as those of the above adsorption experiments, and the removal efficiency is calculated to be 7.3% for carbofuran, 26.7% for carbaryl, and 11.7% for pirimicarb ( and S18), respectively. elements.content: In summary, by employing the thiophene-functionalized dicarboxylic acid to assemble with d10 ions in the presence of a flexible ancillary ligand, we successfully synthesized two 3D microporous MOFs. Among them, compound 1 is a four-fold interpenetration network, and compound 2 is a noninterpenetrated framework. In particular, both compounds 1 and 2 could be efficient luminescent sensory materials for high selectivity and sensitivity to environmental contaminants, especially for Hg­(II), Cu­(II), Cr­(VI), and salicylaldehyde while yet remaining unperturbed by other molecules that might coexist. This is the first observation, to our knowledge, where an MOF is used as a fluorescent sensor capable of recyclable detection of Hg­(II), Cr­(VI), and salicylaldehyde. The luminescent sensing mechanism was investigated in detail as well. Furthermore, compound 2 is one of the rare cases of a high-performance MOF trapping 2,4-dichlorophenol from a contaminated methanol solution. Attempts to improve adsorption recyclability of compound 2 toward pesticides are currently underway in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, by employing the thiophene-functionalized dicarboxylic acid to assemble with d10 ions in the presence of a flexible ancillary ligand, we successfully synthesized two 3D microporous MOFs. Among them, compound 1 is a four-fold interpenetration network, and compound 2 is a noninterpenetrated framework. In particular, both compounds 1 and 2 could be efficient luminescent sensory materials for high selectivity and sensitivity to environmental contaminants, especially for Hg(II), Cu(II), Cr(VI), and salicylaldehyde while yet remaining unperturbed by other molecules that might coexist. This is the first observation, to our knowledge, where an MOF is used as a fluorescent sensor capable of recyclable detection of Hg(II), Cr(VI), and salicylaldehyde. The luminescent sensing mechanism was investigated in detail as well. Furthermore, compound 2 is one of the rare cases of a high-performance MOF trapping 2,4-dichlorophenol from a contaminated methanol solution. Attempts to improve adsorption recyclability of compound 2 toward pesticides are currently underway in our laboratory.

Into a flask flushed with argon, 2,5-dibromo-1,4-benzenedicarboxaldehyde (2 g, 6.85 mmol) and K2CO3 (3.8 g, 27.5 mmol) were added to 30 mL of DMF. After that, ethyl 2-mercaptoacetate (1.5 mL, 13.7 mmol) was added dropwise to the mixture, followed by refluxing for 20 h. The reaction mixture was then brought to room temperature and poured onto a water/ice mixture. The formed beige precipitate was filtered, washed with water, and dried under air. The crude product was purified by silica gel chromatography (CH2Cl2:petroleum ester, 2:1) to afford benzo-(1,2;4,5)-bis­(thiophene-2′-carboxylic acid ethyl ester) (0.98 g, 43%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6, δ ppm): 8.74 (s, 2H), 8.26 (s, 2H), 4.37–4.42 (m, 4H), 1.35 (t, 6H). EI MS m/z: 334 (100%). MP: > 300 °C.

Ester (1 g, 3 mmol) and sodium hydroxide (7.88 g, 0.20 mol) were refluxed in ethanol/water mixture (200 mL) overnight. The resulting solution was acidified, and the formed precipitate was filtered off and washed with water, yielding pure acid benzo-(1,2;4,5)-bis­(thiophene-2′-carboxylic acid) (1.58 g, 95%) of sufficient purity. Anal. Calcd for C12H6O4S2: C, 51.79; H, 2.17%; found: C, 51.91; H, 2.21. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6, δ ppm): 8.74­(s, 2H) 8.21 (s, 2H). EI MS m/z: 278 (100%). MP: > 300 °C.

[Zn­(L)­(BBI)·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (29.7 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2L (10.7 mg, 0.05 mmol), BBI (9.5 mg, 0.05 mmol), DMF (3 mL), and 2 M HCl solution (three drops) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel container (25 cm3) and heated at 120 °C for 2 days. After cooling to room temperature, yellow crystals were collected (yield: 42% based on Zn). Anal. Calcd for C22H22N4O6S2Zn: C, 46.52; H, 3.90; N, 9.86%; found: C, 46.67; H, 4.12; N, 9.82%. IR spectrum (cm–1): 3129w, 2937w, 2860w, 1671s, 1617s, 1546s, 1450m, 1384s, 1350s, 1316m, 1240w, 1162w, 1111w, 1090w, 1036w, 953w, 911w, 856w, 832w, 778m.

[Cd­(L)­(TPOM)<sub>0.75</sub>]·<italic>x</italic>S (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (15.4 mg, 0.05 mmol), H2L (10.7 mg, 0.05 mmol), TPOM (11.1 mg, 0.025 mmol), and DMA (3 mL) was sealed in a screw-capped vial (5 cm3) and heated at 110 °C for 3 days. After cooling to room temperature, yellow crystals were obtained (yield: 71% based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for evacuated samples of compound 2 (C30.75H22CdN3O7S2): C, 51.15; H, 3.07; N, 5.82%; found: C, 52.23; H, 3.32; N, 5.86%. IR spectrum (cm–1): 3127w, 2936w, 1672m, 1605s, 1540m, 1505m, 1464w, 1398m, 1362m, 1319w, 1285m, 1210m, 1162m, 1019m, 824w, 775m.

cln_elements.content:
Compound 1 crystallizes as a monoclinic system with the centric C2/m space group. There are half of a Zn­(II) atom, half of an L2– anion, half of a BBI bridge, and one disordered free water molecule in the asymmetric unit of 1. As manifested in a, the Zn­(II) center site in a tetrahedral coordination geometry is defined by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two individual L2– moieties [d Zn–O ranging from 2.037(3) to 2.065(4) Å] and two nitrogen atoms from different BBI ligands [d Zn–N = 1.961(3) Å]. Each L2– anion is linked to two Zn­(II) centers by monodentate coordination fashions, and each flexible BBI is attached to two Zn­(II) ions with two terminal imidazole groups adopting trans-configuration, producing a 3D porous framework with dimensions of ca. 14.2 × 21.5 Å2, 22.4 × 18.7 Å2, and 12.1 × 15.2 Å2 (atom-to-atom distance) along a-, b- and c-directions. Such large cavities induce 4-fold interpenetration of the network, which still retains 36.6% (1161.2 out of the 3175 Å3 unit cell volume) solvent accessible void volume after interpenetration. Notably, microporous channels with areas of 7.9 × 5.7 Å2 along the c-axis in 1 are present considering van der Waals distances. Apparently, the free spaces in 1 are occupied by structural disordered free aqua molecules. Further topological analysis reveals that 1 can be described as a 4-connected dia net with a topology symbol of 66 (d).

Crystal Structure of [Cd­(L)­(TPOM)<sub>0.75</sub>]·<italic>x</italic>S (<bold>2</bold>)

Interestingly, compound 2 crystallizes in the chiral space group P42212 with a Flack parameter of 0.52(3), suggesting inversion twinning with a 0.48:0.52 domain ratio. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of one Cd­(II) atom, one L2– moiety, and one-half and one-quarter crystallographically distinct TPOM bridges. As demonstrated in a, the Cd­(II) centers adopt a distorted pentagonal bipyramid arrangement connected by four carboxylate oxygen donors from two independent L2– parts [d Cd–O varying from 2.295(13) to 2.620(9) Å] and three nitrogen atoms from separate TPOM bridges [d Cd–N ranging from 2.308(5) to 2.335(6) Å]. Obviously, each L2– moiety fixes to two Cd­(II) sites with both deprotonated COO groups assuming bidentate-chelating coordination mode, while each flexible TPOM is linked to four Cd­(II) atoms, resulting in a noninterwoven 3D framework. There exist three kinds of open channels with sizes of 6.8 × 6.8, 6.8 × 4.0, and 6.6 × 3.1 Å2 along the a-axis, considering van der Waals distances (b). The effective free volume of 2 is ∼76% of the crystal volume (14979 of the 19602 Å3 unit cell volumes) upon removal of the guest molecules. By simplification of Cd­(II) centers and TPOM moieties as 5- and 4-connected nodes, respectively, the entire framework of 2 can be topologically represented as a (5, 4, 4) trinodal net with point symbol of (4.55.62.7.8)4(54.62)­(42.54)2 (c).

To evaluate the potential of 1 and 2 for the sensing of SA, their luminescent behaviors toward SA at different contents in ethanol emulsions were examined carefully. As depicted in , for compound 1, the reduction in luminescence intensity is proportional to the incremental addition of SA at concentrations from 0 to 450 μM, and the slope of K SV was calculated to be 4453 M–1 deduced from Stern–Volmer equation. For compound 2, the K SV value was 3477 M–1 for SA in the range of 0–900 μM from Stern–Volmer model (). The quenching effect is higher than the value of existing Tb-MOF fluorescent sensor comprising a triphenylamine moiety for SA, showing that small organic molecule SA apparently exerts quenching effects on the fluorescence of compounds 1 and 2.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [Zn(L)(BBI)⋅(H2O)2] (1)

Compound 1 crystallizes as a monoclinic system with the centric C2/m space group. There are half of a Zn(II) atom, half of an L2- anion, half of a BBI bridge, and one disordered free water molecule in the asymmetric unit of 1. As manifested in a, the Zn(II) center site in a tetrahedral coordination geometry is defined by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two individual L2- moieties [d Zn-O ranging from 2.037(3) to 2.065(4) Å] and two nitrogen atoms from different BBI ligands [d Zn-N = 1.961(3) Å]. Each L2- anion is linked to two Zn(II) centers by monodentate coordination fashions, and each flexible BBI is attached to two Zn(II) ions with two terminal imidazole groups adopting trans-configuration, producing a 3D porous framework with dimensions of ca. 14.2 × 21.5 Å2, 22.4 × 18.7 Å2, and 12.1 × 15.2 Å2 (atom-to-atom distance) along a-, b- and c-directions. Such large cavities induce 4-fold interpenetration of the network, which still retains 36.6% (1161.2 out of the 3175 Å3 unit cell volume) solvent accessible void volume after interpenetration. Notably, microporous channels with areas of 7.9 × 5.7 Å2 along the c-axis in 1 are present considering van der Waals distances. Apparently, the free spaces in 1 are occupied by structural disordered free aqua molecules. Further topological analysis reveals that 1 can be described as a 4-connected dia net with a topology symbol of 66 (d).

Crystal Structure of [Cd(L)(TPOM)0.75]⋅xS (2)

Interestingly, compound 2 crystallizes in the chiral space group P42212 with a Flack parameter of 0.52(3), suggesting inversion twinning with a 0.48:0.52 domain ratio. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of one Cd(II) atom, one L2- moiety, and one-half and one-quarter crystallographically distinct TPOM bridges. As demonstrated in a, the Cd(II) centers adopt a distorted pentagonal bipyramid arrangement connected by four carboxylate oxygen donors from two independent L2- parts [d Cd-O varying from 2.295(13) to 2.620(9) Å] and three nitrogen atoms from separate TPOM bridges [d Cd-N ranging from 2.308(5) to 2.335(6) Å]. Obviously, each L2- moiety fixes to two Cd(II) sites with both deprotonated COO groups assuming bidentate-chelating coordination mode, while each flexible TPOM is linked to four Cd(II) atoms, resulting in a noninterwoven 3D framework. There exist three kinds of open channels with sizes of 6.8 × 6.8, 6.8 × 4.0, and 6.6 × 3.1 Å2 along the a-axis, considering van der Waals distances (b). The effective free volume of 2 is ~76% of the crystal volume (14979 of the 19602 Å3 unit cell volumes) upon removal of the guest molecules. By simplification of Cd(II) centers and TPOM moieties as 5- and 4-connected nodes, respectively, the entire framework of 2 can be topologically represented as a (5, 4, 4) trinodal net with point symbol of (4.55.62.7.8)4(54.62)(42.54)2 (c).

To evaluate the potential of 1 and 2 for the sensing of SA, their luminescent behaviors toward SA at different contents in ethanol emulsions were examined carefully. As depicted in , for compound 1, the reduction in luminescence intensity is proportional to the incremental addition of SA at concentrations from 0 to 450 μM, and the slope of K SV was calculated to be 4453 M-1 deduced from Stern-Volmer equation. For compound 2, the K SV value was 3477 M-1 for SA in the range of 0-900 μM from Stern-Volmer model (). The quenching effect is higher than the value of existing Tb-MOF fluorescent sensor comprising a triphenylamine moiety for SA, showing that small organic molecule SA apparently exerts quenching effects on the fluorescence of compounds 1 and 2.
